designScenario.name: Horizontal Stabilizer System
designScenario.description: The Horizontal Stabilizer System is a critical flight control surface responsible for maintaining longitudinal stability and controlling pitch during flight. It comprises a fixed horizontal stabilizer and movable elevator surfaces, which adjust the aircraft's angle of attack and balance aerodynamic forces. The system ensures stable flight by counteracting moments from the main wings and reacting to pilot/autopilot inputs. It is designed to withstand high bending and torsional loads while maintaining precise deflection control across all flight phases, including takeoff, turbulence, and landing.

details.description: Provide adjustable pitch control authority through coordinated movement of elevators and trim tabs.
Maintain longitudinal stability during varying flight conditions through aerodynamic load distribution.
Achieve full elevator deflection range (±30°) within 60ms of control input.
Maintain surface position accuracy of ±0.15° under maximum aerodynamic loads.
Implement triple-redundant hydraulic actuators with mechanical backup linkages.
Include load-limiting mechanisms to prevent overstress during extreme maneuvers.
Design for 50,000 flight-hour service life with corrosion-resistant aluminum-lithium alloys.
Enable in-situ actuator replacement without structural disassembly.

relationships.description: The Horizontal Stabilizer System operates as an integrated subsystem within the broader Flight Surfaces architecture, sharing control logic and power systems
The fixed stabilizer structure provides mounting points and load paths for the movable elevator components
Receives digital control signals from the central actuator control module for precise position control
Trim tabs modify the neutral position of elevators to reduce control forces during steady flight
